Question: Does the video accurately depict Trump visiting Maui after the August 2023 wildfires, or is it manipulated?

Queries.Query 1: Did Donald Trump visit Maui after the August 2023 wildfires?
Queries.Query 2: Is the video of Trump in Maui real or manipulated?

Query 1.title: Does Video Show Trump Visiting Maui After August 2023 Fires ...
Query 1.snippet: Aug 17, 2023 ... In August 2023, social media users shared a video clip purporting to show that former U.S. President Donald Trump had visited Maui, an island in ...

content.content: The claim spread after massive fires that burned in Maui in August 2023 left more than 100 people dead at the time of this writing. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ### Published Aug. 17, 2023 Claim: Online video showed U.S. President Donald Trump visiting Maui in the aftermath of the August 2023 wildfires. Context The footage actually showed Trump visiting Beauregard, Alabama in 2019 after a tornado killed nearly two dozen people in the area. In August 2023, social media users shared a video clip purporting to show that former U.S. President Donald Trump had visited Maui, an island in Hawaii, in the aftermath of that left a swath of destruction and more than 100 people dead as of this writing. "The People's President, Donald J. Trump and our Beautiful First Lady Melania Trump, checking up on the people of Maui after the #MauiFires," an X (formerly known as Twitter) post on Aug. 16, 2023. According to the post, the video showed Trump and his wife, former first lady Melania Trump, walking through wreckage with a FEMA truck in the background, as well as Trump speaking to a group of people saying he had met some of the survivors and family members. > TRUMP Visits Maui Hawaii, A Real President Truly cares.???? > > — STEVE #DREAM BIG...just enjoy the moment (@stevehalilovic) In addition, we found the same claim being trumpeted on other social media platforms, like . This footage didn't show Trump visiting Maui. Instead, this was footage from when he visited Beauregard, Alabama, in 2019, after a tornado killed nearly two dozen people in the area. In the video clip, Trump is heard saying: > These are incredible people. We just met some of the survivors and family members, and what they've been through is incredible. One woman lost 10 people in ... [Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Snopes is widely recognized as a leading fact-checking website. It specializes in debunking misinformation, urban legends, and viral claims, making it a highly credible source. Its commitment to thorough research and citation of reliable sources gives it a strong reputation. It has a consistent track record of accuracy and reliability.

ContentScore.Newness Justification: The article from Snopes was published on August 17, 2023, shortly after the wildfires, making it very recent and relevant to the claim.
ContentScore.Relevance Justification: This evidence directly addresses the question by stating that the video claims Trump visited Maui, which has been debunked, thus helping determine the veracity of the claim.

Query 1.title: Video falsely claims Trump visited Maui amid wildfires| Fact check
Query 1.snippet: Aug 18, 2023 ... Trump has not visited the Hawaiian island of Maui following the devastating wildfires there that killed more than 100 in early August. Video ...

content.content: Video falsely claims Trump visited Maui amid wildfires| Fact check =============== ONLY AT USA TODAY: OUR PORTFOLIO: : 72°F Sunny") fact-checking Add Topic Video of Trump visiting a storm-destroyed area is from 2019, not Maui fires | Fact check ======================================================================================== Gabrielle Settles] USA TODAY The claim: Video shows Trump visiting Maui after wildfires ---------------------------------------------------------- An Aug. 16 Facebook video (, ) shows a TikTok video that features former President Donald Trump and former first lady Melania Trump walking past a FEMA truck in a disaster-struck area and talking with people in a building filled with supplies and clothes. “THE PEOPLE'S PRESIDENT,” reads text on the screen. “Thank you Mr. Trump for checking on the people of Maui!” The Facebook video was shared over 900 times in one day, while the original TikTok video has been shared more than 7,000 times. **Follow us on Facebook!** Our rating: False ----------------- The video is years old and shows the former president's 2019 visit to Alabama after a tornado damaged part of the state. Trump has not visited the Hawaiian island of Maui following the devastating wildfires there that killed more than 100 in early August. Video shows Trump visiting Alabama in 2019 ------------------------------------------ At least have died in wildfires that consumed parts of Maui, the second-largest of the Hawaiian islands, since . But there is no evidence the former president has visited the island. The video shared on Facebook shows then-president Trump delivering remarks to a group of people at Providence Baptist Church in Opelika, Alabama, on March 8, 2019, after the area was struck by a tornado that caused serious damage and left injured. The church was serving as a disaster relief center for those affected. The White House shared footage of the visit on the same day. His full comments can ... [Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: USA Today is a reputable news organization known for its accessibility and wide-ranging coverage. While it provides reliable news, it occasionally prioritizes popular news over in-depth investigative journalism. Nevertheless, it is generally trusted and offers factual reporting.

ContentScore.Newness Justification: The USA Today article is from August 18, 2023, still within the critical timeframe shortly after the event.
ContentScore.Relevance Justification: It explicitly states that Trump did not visit Maui following the wildfires, directly debunking the claim made in the video.

Query 2.title: Fake Trump arrest photos: How to spot an AI-generated image
Query 2.snippet: Mar 24, 2023 ... Truth Social Deepfake of Donald Trump kneeling Truth Social. Former ... "That was a super crude piece of manipulation and yet many ...

content.content: Fake images created by artificial intelligence (AI) tools depicting Donald Trump have appeared on social media over the past week. Many falsely showed the arrest of the former president, who may face indictment over payment of hush money to a woman he allegedly had an affair with. He has not yet been charged with a crime. Many of those sharing the images pointed out they were fake, and they did not appear to fool lots of people - but a few did seem to be tricked. On Thursday, Mr Trump also shared an AI-generated image on his own social media platform Truth Social. It showed him kneeling in prayer. What are some of the tell-tale signs of AI-generated imagery? And how can you distinguish a real from a fake? The images circulating online, like the one above, look hyper-real - more like staged artistic shots than in-the-moment photographs. A closer look shows some obvious giveaways that something isn't quite right. Look at the centre of the image. Mr Trump's arm is much too short, and the police officer on the left is grabbing something that more resembles a claw than a human hand. Similarly, if you focus on Mr Trump's neck, you'll notice that his head looks as if it's been superimposed on the image. Henry Ajder, an AI expert and presenter of the BBC radio series The Future Will be Synthesised, says current technology is not very good at depicting certain body parts, especially hands. "If you zoom in on the images you can often see inconsistencies such as the number of fingers," he says. A simple check of a few news sites is a sure-fire way to verify that Mr Trump hasn't been arrested or even indicted - at least, not yet. If and when Mr Trump does ... [Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The BBC (British Broadcasting Corporation) is one of the world's most respected news organizations, known for its comprehensive coverage and journalistic integrity. It has a strong reputation for accuracy and impartiality. While it may have bias in specific interpretations, its editorial standards are generally high. It provides a vast range of fact-checked content and coverage of global events, making it reliable for verifying news stories.

ContentScore.Newness Justification: The article was published on March 24, 2023, which is over three months old by July 2024, thus receiving a moderate score since it is somewhat outdated but still within the same year.
ContentScore.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses manipulated images regarding Trump but does not directly confirm or deny the specific claim of him visiting Maui after the wildfires. Therefore, it's somewhat relevant but not directly pertinent.

Query 2.title: AI-generated disinformation poses threat of misleading voters in ...
Query 2.snippet: May 14, 2023 ... Former President Donald Trump, who is running in 2024 ... A manipulated video of CNN host Anderson Cooper that Trump shared on his Truth ...

content.content: David Klepper, Associated Press David Klepper, Associated Press Ali Swenson, Associated Press Ali Swenson, Associated Press Leave your feedback WASHINGTON (AP) — Computer engineers and tech-inclined political scientists have warned for years that cheap, powerful artificial intelligence tools would soon allow anyone to create fake images, video and audio that was realistic enough to fool voters and perhaps sway an election. The synthetic images that emerged were often crude, unconvincing and costly to produce, especially when other kinds of misinformation were so inexpensive and easy to spread on social media. The threat posed by AI and so-called deepfakes always seemed a year or two away. No more. Sophisticated generative AI tools can now create cloned human voices and hyper-realistic images, videos and audio in seconds, at minimal cost. When strapped to powerful social media algorithms, this fake and digitally created content can spread far and fast and target highly specific audiences, potentially taking campaign dirty tricks to a new low. The implications for the 2024 campaigns and elections are as large as they are troubling: Generative AI can not only rapidly produce targeted campaign emails, texts or videos, it also could be used to mislead voters, impersonate candidates and undermine elections on a scale and at a speed not yet seen. WATCH: Security expert warns of AI tools’ potential threat to democracy “We’re not prepared for this,” warned A.J. Nash, vice president of intelligence at the cybersecurity firm ZeroFox. ”To me, the big leap forward is the audio and video capabilities that have emerged. When you can do that on a large scale, and distribute it on social platforms, well, it’s going to have a major impact.” AI experts can quickly rattle off a number of alarming scenarios in which generative AI is used to create synthetic media for the ... [Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: PBS (Public Broadcasting Service) is known for its educational programming and news coverage, focusing on providing in-depth reporting while maintaining high journalistic standards. However, PBS's funding and potential political influences can sometimes lead to questions about bias. Nevertheless, it is generally a credible source for news and information.

ContentScore.Newness Justification: This article dates from May 14, 2023, placing it within the current context and thus scoring higher for its recency.
ContentScore.Relevance Justification: Discusses manipulated video related to Trump, but not directly about him visiting Maui, thus it has moderate relevance.

Query 2.title: Biden Maui video: pundits falsely claim Biden was asleep at event
Query 2.snippet: Aug 22, 2023 ... ... President Joe Biden fell asleep during a memorial for Maui wildfire victims ... President Donald Trump has used for Biden. Republicans aiming to ...

content.content: Conservative pundits used low-quality video on social media platforms Tuesday to spread a false claim that President Joe Biden fell asleep during a memorial for Maui wildfire victims. Fox News host Sean Hannity was among those who shared low-resolution video on X, the social media app formerly known as Twitter. Hannity’s post was viewed more than 425,000 times within a few hours, and similar videos posted by others received thousands more views on YouTube, Instagram and TikTok. Higher-resolution from the nonpartisan network C-SPAN shows that Biden looked downward for about 10 seconds while he was seated at a table. In the video, Biden watches someone who’s speaking, coughs, looks downward and then nods in agreement with the speaker. Then he looks up again. He later delivered a speech to the same audience. The higher-resolution video shows that Biden kept his eyes open for most of the time he was looking downward. His open eyes aren’t clearly visible in the lower-quality videos. At least one member of Congress, Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas, also shared the lower-resolution version on X. A spokesperson for Nehls said in a statement: “Everyone with eyes can draw their own conclusion about whether President Biden was nodding off in the video.” Asked for comment about the Maui videos, White House spokesperson Andrew Bates said in an email: “It’s unfortunate they feel the need to lie. Instead, they should join him in supporting the people of Maui.” The posts on the country’s largest social media platforms, which largely appear to be spreading unchecked, are the latest test of how Silicon Valley will handle misinformation in the 2024 election cycle — and whether it will enforce its own policies. Low-quality videos are an example of what some misinformation researchers call “”: media that can mislead people through simple techniques, ... [Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: NBC News is a well-established news outlet in the United States, known for its timely reporting and investigative journalism. It has a reasonable record for accuracy, though like many large networks, it can face criticism for perceived bias or sensationalism. Overall, it is a credible source for news and is often used for fact-checking claims made in political contexts.

ContentScore.Newness Justification: Published on August 22, 2023, this piece is just under a year old by July 2024. It's reasonably recent, warranting a decent score.
ContentScore.Relevance Justification: This article discusses a different video of Biden, which does not clearly address the current claim regarding Trump in Maui, thus it is less relevant.

QA.Question: Does the video accurately depict Trump visiting Maui after the August 2023 wildfires, or is it manipulated?
QA.Answer: The video does not accurately depict Donald Trump visiting Maui after the August 2023 wildfires; instead, it is manipulated content. Multiple fact-checking sources have confirmed that the footage being circulated is not recent and actually shows Trump during a visit to Beauregard, Alabama, in March 2019, following a tornado that struck the area, which caused significant damage and loss of life.
